text: two cases of the newly identified
variant of coronavirus have now been
identified here in the united kingdom
the world health organization says early
evidence suggests the variant named
omicron poses an increased reinfection
risk the health secretary has been
talking to reporters about this in the
last few minutes
well late last night i was contacted by
the uk health security agency i was
informed that they have detected two
cases of this new variant omicron in the
united kingdom one in chelmsford the
other in nottingham the two individuals
concerned are self-isolating alongside
their whole household whilst further
tests and sequencing is carried out and
contact tracing the two cases
are linked now we've been always very
clear that we won't hesitate to take
further action if that is what is
required and today i can announce one
thing that we are doing immediately is
carrying out targeted testing and
sequencing of positive cases in the two
areas that are affected and secondly we
are adding four more countries to the
red list from 4am on sunday and those
are angola mozambique malawi and zambia
if anyone has traveled to these four
countries or any of the other recently
registered countries in the last 10 days
then they must self isolate and take pcr
tests
and also later today the prime minister
will be holding a press conference with
the chief scientific advisor to the
government and the chief medical officer
to set out further measures and and
lastly you know this is a real reminder
to us all that this pandemic is far from
over and if there's one thing that
everyone can be doing right now is if
they're eligible please take your
vaccine whether it's your first shot
your second shot or your booster jab if
you are eligible please take your
vaccine are you concerned that this new
variant is in the uk now
of course we were concerned from the
moment we first identified this new
variant as i've said before it is a
deeply concerning new variant and we do
need to learn more about it but the fact
that we now have these two cases in the
united kingdom means that we do need to
take further measures and that's why
i've just set this out today
what impact will this have on
the current vaccine and boost the roll
out
well vaccines remain vitally important
and if anything i think the importance
of them especially the booster vaccine
is now even more important we know this
is new variant out there we don't know
enough about it yet but from what we do
know that we know that you know the
protections that we have especially the
vaccines are hugely important
now that we have two cases
what discussions are you having about
any potential plan b any potential
change in restrictions as we head in
into christmas how does
this change things well we've always
been really clear that you know we will
do whatever is necessary to protect the
progress that we have made as a country
we've come a long way especially since
the summer and we keep all of this under
review and if we need to take further
action we will
what can you tell us about the countries
that the two
people who have this variant where where
have they been where they come from what
do you know about their movements
and do you expect
to be able to contain it to the two
individuals
this case this particular case as i said
these two cases we've identified are
linked and it has been traced to
southern africa one final question
are you concerned at this point given
what we know about this variant
that
we will be looking at potential
changes to the status quo at the moment
as we run into christmas how should
people view this sitting at home making
their plans for christmas thinking
everything was going to be all right
what can you tell them realistically
about what you know about this variant
about what might lie ahead in the next
few weeks well everything we know about
this variant our international partners
know we have been very very open and
that's the right way of course to make
people uh and help them and to to know
why we are concerned and i made a
statement in parliament yesterday to to
set out more of that information but the
one thing i would say again to anyone is
that we've made a lot of progress we all
want to see that protected and if
anyone's sitting at home thinking what
can i do get vaccinated
so that was the health secretary let's
talk to our health correspondent
catherine de costa who's with me now um
so two cases in the uk what will
scientists here be doing right now do
you think on this
so the sequencing and surveillance in
the uk is actually really strong we do
about 20 sequencing in of positive cases
already they and they've been looking at
this they've identified one case in
chelmsford one case in nottingham and
they're saying that they're linked and
as you heard the health secretary say
they are carrying out targeted testing
in those two areas
and the households involved are
isolating at home
and one of the really important public
health messages to get across is that
people coming back from any of those
southern african countries
need to isolate at home for 10 days
and take a pcr test
so on the ground uk health security
agency
will be
closely monitoring at this we have
pcr testing which can actually spot this
mutation because it's what's called the
s-gene drop-out it's picked up in pcr
testing now that's not 100 accurate but
it's like an early heads up that there
could be this could be this new
variant and then that can be taken away
for sequencing to get a confirmation
clearly that's what's happened and
they've identified and confirmed these
two cases so then it's about really
targeted surge testing
and tracing
making sure you get in contact with
those close contacts getting them to
isolate
they're wanting to put a lid on this
because there is this concern about this
particular new variant of concern
because it's so highly mutated there's a
lot of mutations around the spike
protein that's the bit of the virus that
it uses to break through into the body's
cells and if there's lots of changes the
worry is it might be more transmissible
and that it might reduce some of the
protection we get from vaccines
so there are some concerns and the world
health organization has said that there
is some early evidence that might
suggest that this variant increases the
risk of reinfection and might be driving
a wave of infections in south africa so
there is concern among scientists there
but equally
there's a lot we don't know and uh
these travel bans that we've talked
about and the health secretary is
extending to more countries angola
mozambique malawi and zambia from four
o'clock on sunday morning they are
helping to delay
the arrival it won't stop it as we've
seen we've already got two in the uk but
it buys some time because more research
needs to be done in the lab and in the
real world to understand how this
variant responds um so that scientists
know how to act now one of the most
important things as you heard from the
health secretary is vaccination having
first and second doses plus booster
really tops up that protection
and that senior scientists are actually
saying the vaccines are working really
well protecting against serious disease
against other variants
and so they are optimistic that they
will still be effective against this new
variant
okay catherine thank you very much
that's catherine de costa our health
correspondent
and let's get the very latest from the
world health organization we can speak
to dr margaret harris who is
spokesperson for the w.h.o thanks for
being with us uh once again margaret and
how worried are you by this uh omicron
we we know it originated in in africa um
and and flights um have been stopped
because of that but it is now clearly in
europe as well
good afternoon ben i i think we can't
even say it originated in africa what we
do know was it was reported from africa
because the south african science is so
very good and not just so very good but
so very open they reported very very
quickly uh but we can't guarantee that
it actually originated in africa uh now
the reason we made it a variant of
concern so quickly two reasons we got
that information very quickly but also
because then catherine i agree with
everything she said um mentioned the
spike mutations the 32 spike mutations
that is much more than we've seen before
and also the suggestion that it's it
seems to be very transmissible we don't
know that yet and we really need to get
much more information as quickly as
possible and and as we get that try to
get that information we are in a sense
playing for time as a scientist trying
to investigate it that's why we've got
all these travel restrictions imposed on
southern african countries not just by
the uk but by other countries too
does the who the world health
organization agree with those travel
restrictions that have been imposed
so our emergency committee under the
international health regulations
basically put it in a way that asks the
countries themselves to make the
decisions based on their risk assessment
and and the science as we understand it
so it's a decision that's taken at
national level and indeed if you do
impose those restrictions the aim is
justice catherine said to buy time to
get ready and get all the things going
like the enhanced surveillance the
sequencing the plans about how you'll
manage people when they come in to
prevent transmission further into your
community
and also
manage your health system and look at
backup and greater capacity in all those
other things that you need to be
planning to do
